seg.seg: (Then come) (Ma)ṇ(i)bhadra and Pūrṇabhadra, the leaders of the Yakṣas.
(Maṇibhadra speaks: Oh brother Pūrṇabhadra! Why did King Vaiśravaṇa order us to make known) the appearance of the Buddha-god the Teacher) on earth through Bādhari the Brahmin?
(Pūrṇabhadre says:) Having seen (that the noble Metrak) will leave his home in order to go to the Buddha-god the teacher. ||
Ma(ṇibhadre says:) ... did not (order) us to make known? Pūrṇabhadra says: By great gods this matter and this task
... (the Śuddhāvāsa gods) told only God Brahmā, and God Brahmā told Indra, and Indra (told)
… (the Śuddhāvāsa gods) told only God Brahmā.
(King) Vai(śravaṇa): Make every effort that Bādhari the Brahmin of Dakṣiṇāpatha will fully understand the rising of the Buddha-god the teacher, and that this one indeed in this (way) ...

Make effort so that Bādhari the Brahmin of Dakṣiṇāpatha will fully understand the rising of the Buddha, the teacher, and that he [Bādhari] indeed in this (way) … (so that) the (noble) Maitreya will immediately come to the Buddha, the teacher. (cf 51)
... the (noble) Metrak will immediately come to the Buddha-god the teacher. || Maṇibhadra says: I know, I (know).
... Once the noble Metrak knows that, he too will leave his home to go to the Buddha-god the teacher. That

… if the noble Maitreya knows [it] and he goes towards the Buddha, the teacher, in order to leave the house, that … pain will come through which will burst (Bādhari’s) heart, [and] hot blood will rise to his throat. (cf 51, slightly different)
... pain will come through which (Bādhari’s) heart will burst. Hot blood will rise to his throat. Thus
... (Purṇabhadre says: ... Look! This) is the Brahmin Bādhari’s dwelling place. || Maṇibhadra says: Go and tell Badhari; (I)
(will go to the noble Metrak and tell him that Indra and) the four kings have ordered to (come) from the divine world to honor his feet with great respect, ...
... || Then Bādhari the Brahmin, cursed by the Brahmin Nirdhana, (thinks) with sorrow during the night
... What is the reason why that Brahmin desires to have my split in seven parts? May he not (succeed) in this (matter)!
... (of the heart), and on the seventh day, will split my head into seven parts.
… of the heart, and if on the seventh day he splits my head into seven parts. (cf 51, slightly different)
... (the heretics will say:) For twelve years Bādhari has performed the sacrifice. Into seen pieces
... the heretics will say: As a result of giving alms, his head ...
the heretics will say, «As a result of giving alms, his head …» (53)

This fragment contains part of the first act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; the text here more or less continues from . The Uy. parallel is MaitrHami 1, 13a5-14a6. The text running from a8 to a7 (= ) has the following Uy. parallels: MaitrHami I, 12a (end)-13a30 and MaitrSiŋgim, Taf. 117 (+10) v. 12f. (47). See also 193-4.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 53-4.

Between verso and the recto side of this fragment a few sentences are missing. We find them in : b2: nṣā tukär yät\ kuyal mā prakte kälpitār\ : 1 || - [pr·] wewñuräṣ\ räskäryo pre yäṣ\ || tmäṣ\ kum[s]e ///. These sentences have their counterparts in MaitrHami (for the Uy. references, cf. 18), but are not quite equivalent to each other. The MaitrHami 1, 13 a3-5 runs as follows: ““But to me alone you are niggardly, being not willing to give me 500 gold coins.” Having thus spoken, Nirdhana the Brahmin goes away with great wrath”. Some explanations of the Tocharian version are necessary here. About tukär, § 77, Anm., mentions this word, but without any explanation. Perhaps, according to MaitrHami, the sentence can be translated in the following way: “Finally on the last day you are niggardly to me.” There is some kind of fixed expression tukär i- “to be niggardly”. The next sentence can be translated: “Why are you not punished?”. After the double stroke, - [pr.] is to be completed as täpreṃ. The next sentence may be translated: “Having spoken in this way, he goes away in great wrath.” kum[s]e/// is completed to kumseñc. The last sentence reads roughly: “Then the two Yakṣas come.” See MaitrHami 1, 13 a5 ff.; cf. MaitrHami 1, 13 a6-9 and 48, Taf. 11, v. 1ff.
Cf. MaitrHami 1, 13, a10-13 (cf. 18) and 48, Taf. 11, v. 2-8.

The first sentence in this line is completed according to : b5. There is something lost before. See MaitrHami 1, 13, a19-20: “Maṇibhadra says: “Such being the case, why did he not order us to make it known directly to the noble Metrak?””
For the second sentence in this line, cf. MaitrHami 1, 13, a21-22.
Cf. MaitrHami 1, 13, a23-26.
Completed according to : b7; cf. MaitrHami 1, 13, a26-28.
Cf. MaitrHami 1, 13, a29-30 and MaitrHami 1, 13 b1-2.
Cf. MaitrHami 1, 13, b3-5.
wākaṣäṃ (= wākaṣ-äṃ) is the correct reading, like at the end of kāpaṣäṃ (= kāpaṣ-äṃ), later in this line. For the end of this line cf. MaitrHami 1, 13 b8-9.
The following leaf in ’s edition of the Turfan version, Taf. 12, p. 49, is misplaced. According to MaitrHami, this passage must be put above, cf. , commentary to a1.

toṣ: before final -ṣ\, one would like to restore (tränkä)ṣ\. See MaitrHami 1, 13 b10-12. But there are difficulties. In MaitrHami, there is one sentence more: “Then you see!”; in TA, the imperative “you see!” ought to be pälkār, of which the last letter is not -ṣ, but -r. There are, however, on the manuscript some traces of the syllable to before -ṣ, so that we get a correct form of a demonstrative, fem. nom. pl. of säs “this”.
näṣ: So to be completed, 1st person singular pronoun.
Completed according to MaitrHami 1, 13 b14-16.

warśeṃ: this word doesn’t appear elsewhere. MaitrHami has: “Afterwards Bādhari the Brahmin (20) calls to mind Nirdhana the Brahmin’s (21) curse.” Therefore, warśeṃ may mean “curse”. kto, past participle of kät- “to scatter”. On warśeṃ, 26 notes: kto, from kät- “(zu Boden) streuen”. But this semantic extension: warśeṃ, “zu streuen” –> “fertigmachen”, is nothing but fanciful. This may be confirmed by MaitrHami 1, 13 b21.
Cf. MaitrHami 1, 13 b22-25.
The reading of the destroyed original fragment remains difficult. Cf. MaitrHami 1, 13 b28.
Cf. MaitrHami 1, 13 b29.
Cf. MaitrHami 1, 14 a1-3.

This fragment contains part of the first act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; the text here more or less continues from [[YQ I.6]]. The Uy. parallel is MaitrHami 1, 13a5-14a6. The text running from [[YQ I.6]] a8 to [[YQ I.7]] a7 (= [[A 215]]) has the following Uy. parallels: MaitrHami I, 12a (end)-13a30 and MaitrSiŋgim, Taf. 117 (+10) v. 12f. ([[Tekin 1980]]: 47). See also [[Pinault 1999]]: 193-4.

The translation and the following commentary are adapted from [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 53-4.
